rationale: Date of birth is a required demographic field in all EHRs and is always directly available.
Sex is a required demographic field captured during registration and is universally available in EHR data.
Frequently required across oncology trials but inconsistently documented; can be inferred from clinical notes describing functional status, mobility, and activities of daily living.
Commonly required but rarely explicitly documented; can be predicted from disease stage, comorbidities, performance status, and prognostic indicators in the EHR.
Weight and BMI are routinely captured in vital signs; nutritional assessments are typically documented during oncology intake.
Smoking status is a standard social history field captured during intake and routinely documented in EHRs.
Requires FISH, IHC, or NGS molecular testing that cannot be reliably inferred from standard clinical EHR data.
Requires molecular/genomic testing (PCR, NGS) on tumor tissue; cannot be predicted from standard EHR data.
Requires specialized molecular testing (FISH, NGS) that must be performed prospectively on tumor tissue.
Requires genomic sequencing or targeted mutation panels; cannot be inferred from clinical or laboratory EHR data.
Requires comprehensive genomic profiling or NGS testing that must be performed on tumor specimens.
Requires immunohistochemistry assay on tumor tissue with specific antibody clones; cannot be predicted from clinical data.
Requires IHC and/or FISH testing on tumor tissue; expression levels cannot be inferred from standard EHR data.
Requires specialized assays such as flow cytometry, PCR, or NGS-based testing that must be performed prospectively.
Histology is documented in pathology reports which are standard components of oncology EHR records.
Universally required for trial matching but often fragmented across imaging, pathology, and clinical notes; benefits from NLP-based inference and consolidation.
Pathologic diagnosis is documented in pathology reports and is a standard structured element in oncology EHRs.
Tumor size, location, and characteristics are documented in pathology and radiology reports within the EHR.
Commonly required but RECIST measurability is rarely explicitly stated; can be inferred from imaging reports describing lesion dimensions.
Critical for trial eligibility but may be scattered across multiple imaging reports and clinical notes; benefits from aggregation and inference.
Often required post-treatment but not always explicitly documented; can be inferred from surgical pathology and post-treatment imaging.
Frequently required across trials but requires inference from longitudinal imaging comparisons and clinical assessments documented in notes.
Important for eligibility but often requires inference from treatment history, disease-free intervals, and new findings on imaging.
Commonly required criterion but requires aggregation of brain imaging results and may need inference of stability/treatment status.
Liver function tests (AST, ALT, bilirubin) are routine laboratory values directly available in structured EHR data.
Creatinine and calculated GFR/CrCl are standard laboratory values routinely available in EHR data.
CBC components (ANC, platelets, hemoglobin) are routine labs directly available as structured data in EHRs.
General organ function is assessed through routine laboratory panels that are standard structured EHR data.
LVEF is commonly required but echocardiograms may not be recent or routine; may need inference from available cardiac imaging or identification of missing data.
ECG results including QTc intervals are documented in cardiology reports and are typically available when performed.
PFTs are often required for thoracic oncology trials but not routinely performed; when available, may need extraction from unstructured reports.
Important safety criterion but may be underdiagnosed or documented inconsistently; can be inferred from imaging findings, diagnoses, and treatment history.
Blood pressure is routinely captured in vital signs and hypertension diagnoses are documented in problem lists.
Commonly required but historical events may be inconsistently documented; can be inferred from imaging, diagnoses, and anticoagulation history.
Coagulation labs (PT, INR, PTT) are available as structured data; bleeding history is documented in problem lists and notes.
Current and historical anticoagulant use is documented in medication lists and administration records.
Vascular diagnoses are captured in problem lists and procedure histories within the EHR.
Critical for immunotherapy trials but may be underreported in problem lists; can be inferred from diagnoses, immunosuppressive medications, and specialty notes.
Active infections are documented through diagnoses, culture results, and antibiotic prescriptions in the EHR.
Hepatitis serology results are available as structured laboratory data when testing has been performed.
HIV testing results are available as structured laboratory data; status can also be inferred from antiretroviral medications.
TB testing results (PPD, IGRA), diagnoses, and treatment history are documented in structured EHR data.
EBV serology and viral load results are available as structured laboratory data when testing is performed.
Important for immunotherapy eligibility but requires inference from diagnoses, immunosuppressive medications, and laboratory values.
Frequently required but cancer history may be incomplete in problem lists; benefits from inference across oncology notes and pathology records.
Chemotherapy and systemic therapy administration is documented in medication administration records and treatment summaries.
Immunotherapy agents are documented in medication administration records with specific drug names readily identifiable.
Targeted therapy medications are documented in medication records and can be identified by drug class.
Chemotherapy administration is well-documented in medication administration records and oncology treatment summaries.
Anti-VEGF agents (bevacizumab, ramucirumab) are documented in medication administration records.
Radiation therapy is documented in procedure records and radiation oncology treatment summaries.
Concurrent chemoradiation can be identified from overlapping chemotherapy and radiation treatment dates in the EHR.
Treatment intent is commonly required but often not explicitly documented; requires inference from treatment timing relative to surgery.
Specific drug names are documented in medication administration records and can be directly queried.
Surgical procedures are documented in procedure codes and operative notes within the EHR.
Determination of resectability requires prospective surgical evaluation and multidisciplinary assessment that cannot be reliably inferred from existing data.
Nodal staging is important for lung cancer trials but may be fragmented across pathology and imaging; benefits from aggregation and inference.
Imaging study completion and dates are documented in radiology information systems integrated with the EHR.
Physical specimen availability and adequacy for future testing cannot be reliably determined from EHR data alone; requires pathology/biobank verification.
Germline genetic testing requires specialized assays that must be performed prospectively; results cannot be inferred from clinical data.
Prior toxicities are commonly required but inconsistently graded; can be inferred from diagnoses, labs, dose modifications, and clinical notes.
Last treatment dates are documented in medication administration records allowing direct calculation of washout periods.
Current medications and active treatment regimens are documented in medication lists and oncology treatment plans.
Clinical trial participation may not be reliably captured in standard EHR data; requires inference from research notes or external trial databases.
Allergies and drug hypersensitivities are documented in dedicated allergy lists within the EHR.
Contraindications often require inference from multiple data elements including diagnoses, medications, and clinical assessments.
Corticosteroid prescriptions and doses are documented in medication lists and administration records.
Transplant procedures are documented in surgical history and problem lists with associated immunosuppression regimens.
Vaccination records including vaccine types and dates are maintained in immunization registries linked to EHRs.
Pregnancy tests are routine labs and pregnancy/lactation status is documented during intake assessments.
Willingness to use contraception is an administrative/consent requirement that requires prospective patient confirmation.
GI conditions and functional status are documented in diagnoses, procedure notes, and gastroenterology consultations.
Commonly relevant for thoracic oncology but may require aggregation from multiple imaging reports and procedure notes to determine current status.
Neurological and psychiatric diagnoses are documented in problem lists and specialty consultation notes.
Thyroid function tests (TSH, T3, T4) are routine laboratory values available as structured EHR data.
Diabetes diagnoses, HbA1c levels, and diabetes medications are well-documented in structured EHR data.
Wound healing status is relevant for surgical trials but not routinely documented; may require inference from surgical notes and clinical assessments.
Urinalysis and urine protein quantification are available as structured laboratory data in the EHR.
Corneal conditions are documented in ophthalmology notes and problem lists when present.
Current medications are available in medication lists allowing computational assessment of potential drug interactions.
Consent is a prospective administrative requirement that cannot be predicted from clinical EHR data.
Ability to comply with study procedures requires prospective assessment and cannot be reliably predicted from EHR data.
Investigator judgment and discretionary assessments require prospective clinical evaluation at the time of screening.
Treatment dates are documented in medication administration and procedure records allowing direct timing calculations.
Active medical conditions are documented in problem lists, recent diagnoses, and clinical notes.
Implanted devices (pacemakers, ports) are documented in procedure history and problem lists.
Blood product transfusions are documented in medication/blood bank administration records.
Eligibility for locoregional interventions requires prospective multidisciplinary assessment and cannot be reliably inferred from existing data.
Address and demographic information are standard registration fields available in all EHR systems.
Common eligibility requirement but often requires inference from treatment history, lines of therapy, and disease progression documentation.
Determination of treatment amenability requires prospective clinical assessment and multidisciplinary evaluation.
Serum tumor markers (CEA, CA-125, PSA) are structured laboratory values available in EHR data when ordered.
